) is the second largest city in
with a population of 100,000. It is a Hanseatic city and a university town. It is the oldest city in

value: File:Tartu kesklinn (city center) from the hill.jpg
Tartu city center from the Toomemägi hill

, in the center of Estonia. The Emajõgi River, which connects the two largest lakes of Estonia, flows for 10 km within the city limits.
Being a student town, English is widely understood. As usual, the older people are more likely to only speak Estonian and Russian; however most can understand English if you speak clearly.
) is located 10 km south of the city center. As of January 2013, Tartu is served by a single Finnair/Flybe flight from
(daily except for Sa). The airport is, therefore, little more than an embarkation/disembarkation point. If you want to rent a car, book in advance. Don't expect any food at the airport. An

provides door-to-door service from the airport at €4. They can also pick you up before departure (+372 505 4342)

Alternatively, you can fly to
, which is only 180 km away with buses to Tartu running directly from the airport.
(250 km from Tartu) may be an option as well - the Latvian flag carrier AirBaltic, which flies between Riga and a number of European destinations, runs a
between the Riga Airport and Tartu for its passengers. The journey lasts a little over 3.5 hours and the coach arrival and departure times in Tatru are at nighttime (2-3 AM).

at Turu 2, which is across the street from the Kaubamaja department store, 5-10 min walk from the central square of Tartu. The tiny building hosts a ticket office, luggage room, decent cafeteria, and R-kiosk. If you need more, head to the nearby shopping mall. When arriving from Tallinn, you can also get off the bus at one of the stops in the city center.

Bus schedules and fares within

depart several times an hour between 5AM and midnight, and stop at the Tallinn airport. The journey takes 2.5 to 3 hours and costs €8-10, before a discount available with an ISIC card. Some buses have free wireless internet and free drinks available. Note that Friday afternoon departures from Tartu to Tallinn (and Sunday night Tallinn-to-Tartu) are usually crowded during the school year as lots of students go home for the weekend.

Regular buses also run between Tartu and

(6 hr).

Tartu is a stop of international buses running between
(4 hr). These buses typically run overnight, which makes their schedule from Tartu somewhat inconvenient. Another international route is from Tartu to
(4 hr, note that websites and timetables use the Estonian name

Tartu's train station is located only 1 km from the city center (end of J. Kuperjanovi street), but it is not in the city center, and it is not well signposted either. The easiest way to find the train station is to follow Riia street uphill until you see the railway, and turn right along the tracks. The station building amply adorned with wooden carvings is a nice example of Estonian architecture. Inside, you won't find more than a kiosk (not even an R-kiosk!) and a ticket machine.
operates several daily trains between Tartu and

via Tapa. The journey takes 2.5 hr (express train) to 3.5 hr (regular train) and costs €8 for 2nd class, or €10 for 1st class on an express train (regular trains are cheaper than 2nd class and, thus, even less comfortable). 1st class passengers get free Wi-Fi and tables between the seats. Express trains have a small bar with coffee, snacks, and refreshments.

Trains also run between Tartu and
on the Latvian border, with one daily connection further to
(5 hr). Railway tracks likewise go in the direction of
, but you can only reach the small station of
on the Russian border. This station is less than 1 km from the 24/7 checkpoint, which is open for pedestrians. Once you are on the Russian side, catch a taxi or simply walk to the bus station of
(2 km from the border), and continue to

An excellent day trip is to drive from Tallinn to Tartu. Outside of Tallinn, it is a two-lane paved road with some construction ongoing to upgrade it. It takes two to two and a half hours. There are few sights of interest along the way. The terrain is flat and most of the road is bracketed by a birch trees and a few pines. Sam's Grill (about 1/2 way between Tallinn and Tartu) or a bit fancier Põhjaka Mõis are recommended as a place to stop. There is a gas station (Statoil) some kms away.
operates ferry services between Tartu and Lake Peipus and Lake Lämmijärv.
Tartu's Old Town is navigable by foot, but if you want to go out of Old Town, there's public transportation.

operates a network of 19 intracity bus lines and 2 night bus lines around Tartu. Single tickets cost €0.75 from a newsstand or €1 from the driver. 10 single tickets from a newsstand cost €8. A ticket for 1 day costs €2, 1-hour ticket costs €1. 10-day ticket costs €8. On lines 6A, 31, 32 and 33, which are being operated by Automen, the ticket costs €1.

Since 2011, all public transport buses are colored red with white curvy decorations.

Important lines are:

value: 8 to Lõunakeskus and Anne Kanal (popular beach)
2, 3, 3A, 5, 9 and 14 to Central Market and Bus Station

Bus line 69 is free, and runs between the bus station and the Lõunakeskus shopping center on the edge of town. As this is a sponsored line, its buses do not have the red-and-white color scheme of regular municipal buses.

value: name=Main building of the University of Tartu
content=The kissing students fountain is a symbol of Tartu.
content=Neighborhood where all of the streets are named after soup ingredients. Features charming old wooden houses.

content=Classicist style structure was built as a town palace in 1790. The building is popularly called Catherine´s House. The legend has it that Empress Catherine II made a short stay there. It is not true, though.

content=This nondescript building was known as the Gray House and was the headquarters of the Estonian KGB. It tells the story of how the prisoners were treated there, and some stories about the Estonian resistance heroes, the Forest Brothers. The museum is small and does not have a very big sign, so look carefully.
Statue of Oscar Wilde and Eduard Vilde in Tartu
name=Botanic Garden of the University of Tartu
content=Many monuments, statues and historical buildings
directions=Located on cross of the streets Vahi and Narva maantee
content=14th century church is famous for its thousands of medieval terracotta figures.
directions=on top of the Dome Hill

content=From the 13th century and were dedicated to apostles St. Peter and Paul. Today the choir part houses the Tartu University History Museum, and the towers are reconstructed to sightseeing platforms.
content=An outstanding redbrick Finnish National Romanticist style building by the famous Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen.
content=A Neogothic Lutheran church from 1903, is built on the grounds of the first general Estonian song festival which took place in 1869.
content=A beautiful neo-Historical redbrick building from 1899.
content=A two-story church, designed by architect V. Lunski, with cupolas inspired by the Old Russian church architecture. It was deconsecrated 40 years ago but reconsecrated in summer 2003.
content=An early classical church built in 1783 with typical Russian classical elements. It´s located on the same place as the St. Mary Magdalene Church of a Dominican cloister founded before 1300.

content=Dug into the side of the hill in 1767 as part of the complex of the bishop’s citadel. It was used as a gunpowder cellar until 1809. Until 1982 it served as a storage room for many different enterprises, and was later developed into a eating place. Today, the building hosts a bar/restaurant of the same name.

content=Construction of the building began in 1763 as military barracks. Onto its ruins was built the university hospital in 1808, which functioned until 1990. Since 1993, the national court is again in Tartu, which is Estonia’s supreme judiciary court.
directions=on the old castle ruins on the Dome Hill
content=The observatory, designed by university architect J.W. Krause, was built at the beginning of the 19th century. Working place of many famous astronomers including Struve.

content=One of the first buildings of the re-opened Tartu University which was built in 1803-1805 according to the drawings of university architect J. Krause. Today the visitors are offered an exhibition of the history of medicine with preparates.
name=Aristocratic dwellings and former teachers' college

content=Late 18th century building. Duchess Barclay bought the house in 1819 after the death of her husband, Barclay de Tolly. The longitudinal wall of the building toward the river was built on the basis of the old town wall, while the other side was built on a new foundation. This is why the house is now askew and is popularly called the Tower of Pisa.
directions=Kalevi St is the continuation of Ülikooli St after Riia St

content=Congregates several creative enterprises and creates therefore a creative atmosphere. The three buildings of the centre were built between 1830 and 1913 and represent different architectural styles: historicism and Art Nouveau.
content= Built in the 19th century and spans Lossi Street.
content=Built in 1913 in honour of the 300th jubilee of tsarist Russia’s Romanov Dynasty, which is memorialised on the bridge by the dates 1613-1913.
directions=Stand in the main square and look towards the river

content=Stands on the site of the original stone bridge of Tartu which was built in 1784 and blown up by the Soviets in WWII. This new bridge is only for pedestrians and allows you to do one of the most loved cultural activities of Tartu, walk over the top of the arch after a big night in the club. Just don't let the cops catch you.

During the last decade, Tartu has seen several interesting pieces of modern architecture being built. They are well worth a visit and give an insight of how people in modern Tartu think and live, in addition to traditionally history-driven image of the city. Some of them are right in the city-centre. See the yellow markers on the official [Tartu Modern Architecture map http://www.tartu.ee/nyydisarhitektuur]. The map is in Estonian only, but selected images speak louder than words.

value: content=The biggest movie theater in Tartu.
content=A popular movie theatre. It has two movie screens and first-rate Dolby SR/DTS sound system.
content=Offers various cruises for up to 30 people along River Emajõgi.

content=The salt chamber has two separate treatment rooms. One chamber is for adults and the other is for children. Natural salt treatment has no harmful side effects and it stimulates body's immune and defense mechanisms.
price=12€, discounts for students, families, etc
content=Swimming pool, water park, fitness center
content=Third week of July, exact dates vary from year to year. Medieval festival featuring fairs, festivities, exhibitions, concerts, dances, merchants and tradesmen.
content=Film festival in August. Themes include love and tolerance.
content=Film festival at the end of November.
Main building of the University of Tartu

content=Established in 1632, it's one of the oldest universities in Europe. The main building was built in 1804-1809 according to university architect Johann Wilhelm Krause's plans in classical architecture. It includes the historic lock-up on the attic, Assembly Hall and the Tartu University Art Museum which displays ancient art.
directions=100 metres from the Bus Station
content=Department store with several floors full of fascinating things to buy. "Kaubamaja" belongs to Kaubamaja consortium.
directions=take bus no. 18 from the city centre.
content=Features a wide range of small boutiques, as well as a big department store Maksimarket.
directions=At Annelinn, a small suburb of Tartu. Take bus 1, 5, 15, 17 from the city centre, just opposite the Kaubamaja.
(big department store), as well as clothes shop, lots of small boutiques and other small shops.
content=Loov Gallery sells souvenirs produced by young Estonian artists, ranging from jewelry and accessories to paintings.
content=Different pizza and pancake dishes (both as desserts and as main courses), soups, rice dishes, etc.
content=Authentic Asian cuisine, good price soups and meals of the day.
content=Built inside an ancient gunpowder cellar

- small park where consuming light (<6%) alcohol is allowed between 15 March and 15 October. It's the only public place in the city where drinking is legal so in the evenings it's full of students and homeless.
In a typical pub, a 0.5L beer usually costs €2. Almost all popular beers are near or more than 5% alcohol content.

value: content=Jazz Club. Many sporting events (mainly football) are broadcasted.
content=English style pub. Offers 40% discounts on any alcoholic beverages after 20:00.
content=Located in a basement cellar with minimal seating, it can get crowded on the weekends. Popular among students and foreigners.
content=Legendary meeting place for students and alternative fashion people. Popular among foreigners.
content=An alternative club with concerts, theater performances, seminars, etc.
content=Apartments are located in a historical house on the main square. They offer spacious and clean apartments with all the equipment and privacy needed.
directions=on the other side of the cathedral hill
content=Small guest house. The lady who runs it speaks a little English but she is delightful and you can communicate without too much hassle. Best to email ahead.
content=Self-service accommodation in apartments with all comforts.
price=4 bed dorm: €15. Private room (1 person): €22
content=English speaking, overlooking the Town Square, Excellent kitchen and bathrooms.
directions=right across from the bus station
address=3 different locations: Raatuse 22, Narva mnt. 27 and Pepleri 14
content=Best rooms go quickly so book ahead.

content=In the Annelinn suburb, is a quality budget hotel. All rooms are equipped with Sat-TV and an internet connection. Located just few minutes by car from Tartu Town Hall square, with frequent bus service from right in front of the hotel.
content=49 rooms including 2 suites with saunas. Amenities include safe-box, hairdryer, cable TV, mini-bar, phone and complimentary wireless internet. Restaurant serves authentic Estonian food.
directions=on the banks of the Emajõgi River, near the bus station
content=200 standard rooms and 5 business class rooms.
